title: 108_hr2601
content: The "Public Domain Enhancement Act" may be cited as the short title of this legislation. The Congress finds that the copyright clause in the US Constitution grants Congress the power to promote the progress of science and arts by securing exclusive rights to authors for limited times. This serves to provide economic incentives for authors to create new works and promotes society's interest in the free flow of ideas and commerce. "The copyright system provides economic incentives for creators and promotes the free flow of ideas and commerce. The limited copyright term ensures that the public can benefit from artists' work. Both commercial and noncommercial creators rely on a healthy public domain for creating and distributing works." The public domain is essential for various industries like book publishing, movie production, and educational institutions. It provides raw material for new creations and allows for the free flow of historical and cultural content on platforms like the World Wide Web. Under current law, copyright protection is granted to works published as early as 1923, but the majority of older works are no longer commercially available. Only 2 percent of works between 55 and 75 years old retain commercial value. This prevents entities from building upon and preserving abandoned works. The existing copyright system prevents entities from building upon and preserving abandoned works, contrary to the intent of the Framers of the Constitution and Congress. Older works may not have commercial value but can be useful to historians, artists, and teachers. The dissenting opinion argues that the current copyright system goes against the original intent of the Constitution and Congress by preventing abandoned works from entering the public domain. It is suggested that a mechanism be established to allow abandoned American copyrights to be accessible to the public. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE FEE FOR PUBLISHED UNITED STATES WORKS. The definition of "United States work" in section 101 of title 17, United States Code, is amended for sections 306 and 411. Section 302 of title 17 is amended for works created on or after January 1, 1978, regarding the duration of copyright. Section 303(a) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to section 306 for works created but not published or copyrighted before January 1, 1978. This includes changes to the language regarding copyright and exceptions, as well as conditions related to section 306. Section 304 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to section 306, specifying conditions for subsisting copyrights. This involves changes to language regarding copyright exceptions. This involves changes to language regarding copyright exceptions, such as inserting specific clauses in subparagraphs and subsections. A maintenance fee of $1 is required to keep the copyright in any published United States work in force, due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter until the end of the copyright term. The Register of Copyrights charges a $1 fee to maintain the copyright in any published United States work. The fee is due 50 years after first publication or on December 31, 2004, and every 10 years thereafter. Failure to pay the fee within 6 months after the due date will result in the copyright expiring. Ancillary or promotional works connected to the maintained copyright are also covered. The maintenance fee for copyright in a work must be paid to the Register of Copyrights, along with a prescribed form. Ancillary or promotional works related to the maintained copyright are also covered. The maintenance fee for published United States works is amended in Section 708(a) of title 17, United States Code. This includes adding a new paragraph (10) for the maintenance fee under section 306. The Register of Copyrights must establish procedures within 12 months to ease the submission of forms and make the information easily accessible to the public under section 306(c) of title 17, United States Code.
